Yes, I worked with both Fit and FitNesse for quite a while before
deciding =
to develop Concordion.

Fit and FitNesse are great, but they are typically =
used as scripting
tools. Concordion makes a different set of design choices=
 to try and
make it easier to write specifications and harder to write scri=
pts.

There are big advantages to writing specifications rather than
script=
s:

- Longer lives. When you move to the next technology, you can reuse
  t=
he specifications since they are implementation-independent.

- Agility. Se=
parating examples of required behaviour from the 
  mechanics of testing al=
lows you to refactor the mechanics
  (i.e. the implementation of your syste=
m) without affecting the
  test cases.

Take a look at this page for an exa=
mple of a FitNesse script compared
to a Concordion specification:

http://w=
ww.concordion.org/ScriptingMakeover.html

David
